conclusion: Place the centre of the semicircle at the origin O.
Let the flat face AB lie on the x-axis (A at –R, B at +R).
Any point P(x , y) on the curved surface satisfies x² + y² = R² with y ≥ 0.
The parallel light beam is incident normally on AB, so after entering the glass every ray travels straight upward parallel to the y–axis.
The normal to the surface is the radius OP and the direction of the ray inside the glass is vertical (parallel to OO′). Hence the angle of incidence i is the angle between OP and the positive y-axis.
Using the scalar product of the two unit-vectors, cos i = (OP · OO′)/(|OP||OO′|) = y / R ⇒ sin i = √(1 – cos² i) = √(1 – y²/R²) = |x| / R. Thus, sin i = |x| / R.

At the glass–air interface the largest incidence angle that still allows refraction is the critical angle c, defined by sin c = n₁ / n₂ = 1 / n, where n is the refractive index of the glass and the outside medium is air (n₁ = 1).
A ray will escape if i ≤ c. Using sin i = |x| / R and sin c = 1 / n, |x| / R ≤ 1 / n ⇒ |x| ≤ R / n.
The greatest horizontal distance from the axis that fulfils |x| ≤ R / n is x_max = R / n.
The beam falls symmetrically on both sides of the central axis, so the total width W of the parallel beam that can be admitted is W = 2 x_max = 2 R / n.
Numerical value (if ordinary glass, n ≃ 1.50), W = 2R / 1.50 = (4/3) R ≃ 1.33 R.
The greatest width of the parallel light beam that can enter through the flat face AB and still emerge from the hemispherical surface is W = 2R / n (≈ 1.33 R for common crown glass, n ≃ 1.50).
